questions.text: After an ear infection, a child had limb spasm, pain and difficulty opening mouth. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a child with trismus (difficulty opening the mouth) and tonic limb spasms, following a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), is most consistent with tetanus.

Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani, an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium. Its spores are highly resilient and can enter the body through wounds, abrasions, or, in neonates, the umbilical stump. Once inside, the bacterium produces tetanospasmin, a potent neurotoxin that disrupts normal neuromuscular function.

Clinical features:

  • Early symptoms include trismus, muscle stiffness, pain, back discomfort, and difficulty swallowing
  • As the disease progresses, generalized muscle spasms occur, affecting muscles throughout the body and causing severe pain.
  • Laryngeal muscle involvement in the early stages can result in airway obstruction.
  • Around the second week, autonomic disturbances are often prominent, manifesting as gastrointestinal stasis, excessive sweating, increased tracheal secretions, and cardiovascular events such as blood pressure fluctuations and heart block.
  • Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on the characteristic symptoms and history.

Explanations for other Options:

Myelopathy (Option B): It is Caused due to Spinal cord pathology (trauma, infection, tumor). Key Features Include- Weakness, spasticity, sensory deficits, sometimes bladder/bowel involvement.Myelopathy rarely causes trismus or generalized painful spasms after an ear infection.

Sigmoid sinus thrombosis (Option C): Typically presents with high-grade, intermittent ("picket-fence") fever and headache, but without the characteristic muscle spasms seen in tetanus.

Bezold abscess (Option D): Can develop secondary to mastoiditis from CSOM, presenting with fever, neck swelling, tenderness, and torticollis, but does not cause generalized muscle spasms or trismus.

questions.text:
Which of the following are indications for cochlear implant?
1.Otosclerosis
2.Congenital hearing loss
3.Fixed malleus
4.Aminoglycosides induced hearing loss
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Severe sensorineural hearing loss from birth (congenital) or caused by aminoglycoside toxicity are both recognized indications for a cochlear implant.

Cochlear Implant Indications:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss is the primary indication for cochlear implantation.
  • Specifically, congenital severe-to-profound hearing loss and hearing loss caused by aminoglycoside ototoxicity are classic indications.
  • Cochlear implants are recommended for patients who do not gain sufficient benefit from conventional hearing aids.

Mechanism of Action:

  • The cochlear implant bypasses damaged cochlear hair cells and directly stimulates the auditory (8th cranial) nerve, allowing sound perception.
  • The electrode array is surgically positioned within the scala tympani of the cochlea.
  • A functioning auditory nerve and intact central auditory pathways are essential prerequisites for the procedure.

Components of a Cochlear Implant:

  • External Component:
    • Includes a speech processor and a transmitter, which capture and encode sound.
  • Internal Component:
    • Surgically implanted under the skin and consists of a receiver/stimulator unit with an electrode array that interfaces with the cochlea.

Candidate Criteria for Cochlear Implantation:
 Ideal candidates for a cochlear implant typically meet the following criteria:

  • Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss
  • Minimal or no improvement with conventional hearing aids
  • No medical conditions that contraindicate surgery
  • Realistic expectations regarding outcomes
  • Strong family and social support to assist with post-implant rehabilitation
  • Sufficient cognitive ability to effectively use and benefit from the device

Components:

Key takeaway:

Preoperative Evaluation:

  • Audiological assessment to determine the degree and type of hearing loss.
  • Imaging: High-resolution CT (HRCT) and MRI to assess the cochlear structure, cochlear nerve, and identify any central nervous system abnormalities.

Surgical Approach:

  • Two main techniques are used to access the cochlea:
    • Facial recess approach- via the facial recess
    • Pericanal approach - via the external auditory canal (EAC)
  • The electrode array is inserted into the scala tympani, typically through the round window from the middle ear.

Postoperative Management:

  • The cochlear implant is usually activated 3-4 weeks after surgery.
  • Postoperative evaluation is performed using HRCT; MRI is generally contraindicated due to the implant.

Contraindications:

  • Cochlear aplasia (Michel aplasia) - absence of the cochlea
  • Absence or damage of the cochlear nerve or lesions affecting the central auditory pathways

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about juvenile angiofibroma
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Biopsy done under local anesthesia is the incorrect statement.

Definition and Epidemiology:
 Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males aged 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior nasal cavity near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. The tumor originates from a hamartomatous vascular nidus that proliferates under the influence of testosterone, making it a hormone-dependent tumor.

Clinical Features:
 The tumor can expand into the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, orbit, cheek, or even intracranial space, producing characteristic signs and symptoms:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis - the most common symptom
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasalized speech due to mass effect in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion from Eustachian tube blockage
  • Nasopharyngeal mass that may appear sessile, lobulated, or smooth
  • Additional features: broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, and possible involvement of cranial nerves II, III, IV, and VI
  • In advanced cases, frog-face deformity may develop

Diagnosis:
 Diagnosis is primarily based on clinical examination and imaging studies.

  • Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice.
  • A pathognomonic sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, known as the Holman-Miller sign (Antral sign).

Surgery is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A patient experiences vertigo and vomiting specifically when turning in bed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A patient experiencing vomiting and rotational vertigo, particularly when turning the head in bed, most likely has Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).

Clinical features:

  • BPPV is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by specific head movements.
  • It is not associated with hearing loss or other neurological deficits.
  • The condition arises from a disorder of the posterior semicircular canal, caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) that have become dislodged from the utricle.
  • The vertigo is provoked by positional changes, especially tilting or turning the head toward the affected side.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver, which reproduces vertigo and nystagmus in the affected canal

Pathophysiology:

  • Otoconia migrates into the posterior semicircular canal, interfering with normal endolymph flow and stimulating abnormal vestibular signals, leading to transient vertigo during specific movements.

Steps of the Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre:

  • The manoeuvre starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  • Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  • The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  • The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  • Now the examiner observes the patient's eye for nystagmus.

Explanations for other Options:

Vestibular neuritis (Option B): Characterized by a sudden onset of intense vertigo that can persist for several days to weeks, without any cochlear involvement such as hearing loss or tinnitus.

Ménière's disease (Option C): Presents with sudden episodes of vertigo lasting minutes to hours, accompanied by fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness or pressure in the affected ear.

Labyrinthitis (Option D): Causes unilateral vestibular dysfunction with abrupt, continuous vertigo, often associated with nausea, vomiting, and sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text:
Stridor in a newborn is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
1.Laryngomalacia
2.Subglottic stenosis
3.Laryngeal papilloma
4.Hemorrhagic polyp
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Subglottic stenosis and Laryngomalacia are the causes of stridor in neonates.

Stridor is an abnormal, harsh respiratory sound caused by turbulent airflow through a narrowed segment of the airway. It can occur during inspiration, expiration, or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor: Typically results from obstruction above the vocal cords, such as in the supraglottic region or pharynx. Common causes include laryngomalacia and retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor: Heard during both inspiration and expiration, usually due to narrowing at the glottis, subglottis, or cervical trachea. Examples include laryngeal papillomas, bilateral vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor: Occurs with obstruction of the lower airway, such as the thoracic trachea or bronchi, and is seen in conditions like tracheal stenosis or a bronchial foreign body.
  • Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis presents with stridor in children and not in neonates.
  • Haemorrhagic polyp may present with obstruction but not with stridor.

Key takeaway:

Noisy breathing/ Acute stridor

choices.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: If the pyriform fossa is injured due to a fish bone, which nerve is likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is responsible for irritation.

The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve courses beneath the mucosa along the lateral wall of the pyriform sinus. When a foreign body becomes lodged in this area, it can irritate the nerve. Because the nerve is superficial here, it can be readily targeted for local anesthesia. Pain from carcinoma of the pyriform sinus is often referred to the ear through this nerve.

The pyriform fossa lies on each side of the larynx, forming a lateral food channel that extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold down to the upper end of the esophagus. Its boundaries are:

  • Medial: Aryepiglottic fold and the posterolateral surfaces of the arytenoid and cricoid cartilages
  • Lateral: Thyrohyoid membrane and thyroid cartilage

Explanations for other Options:

Vagus nerve (Option A):The vagus gives off the internal superior laryngeal nerve but its main trunk lies much deeper in the neck, well protected by surrounding structures.
A superficial injury inside the pyriform fossa is unlikely to reach the main vagus.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option C): This nerve ascends in the tracheo-oesophageal groove and enters the larynx below the thyroid cartilage, far away from the mucosal surface of the pyriform sinus.Damage here would cause vocal-cord paralysis, but its location is too inferior and medial to be injured by a fish bone in the fossa.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option D): The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the oropharynx and posterior third of the tongue and passes high in the parapharyngeal space.It does not course through the pyriform sinus, so a local mucosal injury there would not affect it.
